question: List and discuss briefly eight factors that militate against the developement of commercial agriculture in Nigeria.
answer:
Eight factors that militate against the development of agricukature in Nigeria are; (i) Inadequate Land (ii) Poor storaage and processing facilities (iii) Inadequate finance (iv) Inadequate transportation network (v) Lack of farm inputs (vi) Lack of basic amenities (vii) inadequate agricultural education and extension services (viii) poor marketing system.

 (1) Inadequate Land (i) increase in population reduces the size of farmlands. (ii) The type of rand tenure systems Nigeria prevents farmers from acquiring land, (iii) Deforestation contributes to lack of land

(2) Poor storage and processing facilities: (i) Excess produce are wasted due to lack of storage facilities (iii) Storage faciities are expensive to purchase. (iii) improper storage and processing reduce the quantity and quality of the produce.

(3) Inadequate finance: (i) Peasant farmers have no access to loan or credit facilities, (iii) High interest rate charge by banks discourage borrowing. (di) Poor farmers who manage to get loans divert them to other purposes

(4) Inadequate transportation: (i) most farms in Nigeria are not accessible by roads. (ii) Lack of sufficient vehicle  hinders movement of food from rural to urban areas, (iii) High cost of transportation is a problem to commercial farming" (Iv) Some of the existing roads in rural areas are in very bad condition.

(5) Lack of farm input: (i) Farm inputs like tools, fertilizers are inadequate. (ii) Farm inputs are of inferior quality. (iii) Farm inputs even wh-en available are not supplied to farmers at the right time,

(6) Lack of basic amenities; Basic amenities like, electricity, pipe borne water and hospitals are tacking in rural areas

(7) Inadequate agricultural education and extension services: (i) Majority of the farmers cannot read and 'write (ii) They do not know how to apply modern farm inputs (iii) Extension officers are inadequate.

(8) Poor marketing system: (i) There are no organised marketing channels for produce. (ii) There is lack of propel ,pricing for agrlc produce. (iii) The activities of middlemen worsen the marketing of produce.

question:
(a) What does mechaniztion mean in Agriculture?

(b) What are the advantages and disadvantages of mechanization?

(c) State and discuss briefly four limitations of mechanization in Agriculture?
answer:
Mechanization in Agriclture simply means the use of modern farm inputs to increase productivity and efficiency. It also involves the use of motorised equipments like tractors, planters, farm implements like plough, harrow, ridgers etc and also the use of chemicals, improved seeds and fertilizers to increase production.

Advantages of mechanization are (i) Mechanization increases production (ii) It reduces health hazards (iii) it supplements human power for heavy duty job (iv) There is timeliness in farm operation. (v) It encourages large scale farming (vi) It makes naturally difficult and unpleasent manual jobs, easy and pleasant

Disadvantages of mechanization are (i) Displacement of workers (ii) Destruction of soil structure (iii) It causes environmental pollution (iv) There is compaction of soil by machines

Limitations of agricultural mechanization are (i) Economic Limitation: farmers are generally poor. They do not have money to buy inputs like tractors, fertilizers, chemicals, seeds, etc (ii) Technical know-how: Most farmers do not know how to operate machines or apply fertilizers. They do not read instructions attached to the implements. (iii) small holdings of of farmlands: Most farmers cultivate small farmlands because they are poor and as a result of thetype of land tenure system practiced in Nigeria (iv) Lack of maintenance: Farmers cannot repair farm tools and implements. Spare parts are scarce, expensive with no trained personnel to repair machines.

question: Write short notes on the effects of the following farm practices on soil: (a) bush burning, (b) fertlizer application (c) grazing (d) crop rotation
answer:
Bush Burning: (i) It destroys the seeds of weeds, (ii) It destroys soil borne pathogene (iii) it burns the organic matter content of soil (iv) it kills or reduces the number of soil organisms. (v) It exposes the soil to erosion

Fertlizer application: (i) It supplements nutrient content of the soil (ii) it promotes productive capacity of the soil (iii) it increases the population of organisms in the soil (iv) Excessive use of fertilizer can cause soil acidity

Over grazing: (i) It depletes the vegetation of the soil (ii) It exposes the soil to erosion (iii) It destroys the soil structure (iv) It leads to the compaction of the soil

Crop rotation: (i) It increases the yield of crops (ii) It controls erosion and weed growth (iii) It controls pests and diseases (iv) It ensures the fertility of the soil

answer:
(i) For production of crops, (ii) Land is the natural grazing area for lives-tock (iii) Land is used for Wild life and game reserves. (iv)  Land Is used for forestry. (v) Land can also be used for residential and industrial buildings. (vi) Land is used for construction of roads, railway lines etc 

Five factors affecting Availability of land for agricultural production include: (i) Increase in population; Increase in population of the people reduces he availability of land for farming (ii) Land tenure system: The type of land tenure system in Nigeria does not make land available for farming. (iii) Topography: The shape of the land affects its availability. If the land is sloppy, swampy, hilly etc, such land may not be available for farming (iv) Cultural practices: Cultural practices like bush burning and shifting cultivation reduce the availability of land for farming. (v) Soil type: This affects the availability but if the soil is loamy such land will be available for farming

question: Discuss briefly a named oil crop under the following headings (a) climatic and soil requirements (b) planting date, seed rate and spacing (c) nursery practices (d) harvesting (e) processing and storage
answer:
A named oil crop is oil palm (a) Climatic and soil requirement of oil palm include; Temperature requirement is 18°C while rainfall Is 150 - 250crn per annum. It requires a deep loamy soil rich in humus with a pH of 4.5 - 6.0

(b) Planting date: Pre-nursery is August - October. Nursery is nine months later while field planting is March - May a year later . Spacing: (i) Pre-nursery is 7.6cm x 7.6cm (ii) Nursery is 60cm x 60cm while (iii) Field is 7.8 x 9m

(c) Nursery practices; (i) Pre-nursery: Seeds go through certain processes of germination. Germination occurs 15 days later (ii) Nursery: Raised seed trays are used and seedlings are raised till four months later within which weeding, supplying, watering etc are done

(d) Harvesting: Oil palm matures after 3-5 years. Harvesting knives are used to remove mature bunch from the tree.

(e) Processing and storage: Fruits are boiled, Pounded and the seeds and fibres are removed. The thick liquid is later boiled and the oil is removed from the liquid. Oil palm is stored in containers made of  Copper, zinc or aluminium

question:
(a) Describe the process of egg-formation in poultry

(b) Enumerate six functions/roles of the reproductive hormones in animals
answer:
The process of egg formation in poultry is controlled by hormones. The egg is formed partly in the ovary and partly the oviduct. Yolk is formed In the ovary while other proteinous parts are formed in the liver and kidney. The yolk released by the ovary is taken up by infidibuIum and later moved to the oviduct where fertilization takes place The egg moves to the magnum, stay there for three hours and part of the albumen is formed. Chalaza is secreted round the yolk from the magnum. the egg moves to the isthmus where it stays for 1¼ hours and the two shell membrane, are formed. The shape of the egg is also formed in this region. The egg then, moves to the uterus where it slays for 19-20 hours, The Shell is formed in the uterus. The egg is then passed to the vagina where it stays for a very short time before it is laid

Six functions/roles of the reproductive hormones in animals are: (i) Androgen stimulates the development of  male secondary sexual characters and sex behaviours. (ii) It stimulates the optimum condition for spern production (iii) estrogen helps in the production of heat in fernales. (iv) It also regulates menstrual cycle and ovulation (v) progesterone helps in the continuance of pregnancy (vi) Oxytocin helps in causing milk production.

question:
(a) State and discuss briefly four factors of production in Agriculture

(b) List four functions of a farm manager.
answer:
(a) Four factors of production in agriculture are:

(1) Land:  (i) Land refers to where production can take place. (ii) It s the gift of nature (iii) It Is immobile and deteriorates when it ts not properly used. (v) It also refers to soil,water.minerals (v) The reward for land is rent,

(2) Labour: (I) It refers to human effort put into production (ii) it includes personal, family, communal and hired or paid labour. (iii) Labour can be skilled, unkilled or semi-skilled. (iv) The reward for labour is wages or Salary.

(3) Capital; (i) This includes all man-made productive assets which are used in production. (i) It could be fixed, e.g. buildings, vehicles, tools and implements. (iii) It could be working capital e.g. water, feed, drug et.c (iv) The reward for capital is interest.

(4) Entrepreneur or Management: (i) This refers to the person who coordinates, organises and controls the use of other factors of production, (iii) In agriculture, he is referred to as the Farm Manager.

(b)Four functions of a Farm Manager are: (i) Organisation (ii) Administration (iii) Production (iv) Marketing

question: Write short notes on the following as they relate to the marketing of agricultural produce (a) Marketing/commodity Boards (b)  Co-operative Societies (c) Middlemen/Wholesalers (d) Producers
answer:
Marketing/Commodity Boards as they relate to the marketing or agricultural produce are: (i)These are public bodies set up by the government to handle the sales of agricultural products. (ii) They stabilize the prices of produce (iii) They ensure sales promotion of export crops (iv) They render export services to farmers (v) They collect and transport crops.

(b) Co-operative Societies (i) They are trading organisations where the cooperators (members) pool their resources together with a view to making profit (ii) They stimulate competition in produce marketing (iii) They provide storage facilities (iv) They also provide transportation services (v) They can grant loans to members

(c) Middlemen/Wholesalers: (i) They buy goods in large quanitities and sell in small quantities to retailers (ii) They provide storage facilities (iii) They have good transport facilities (iv) They pass information from retailers to producers.

(d) Producers: Theysell directly to consumers (ii) Consumers get goods at reduced prices (iii) Produce get to the consumers fresh.
